p.s: In the following, it will be analysed howShakespeare uses formal and poetic devices in order to illustrate and intensify his view.
The sonnetssonnet's formal structure is typical for a Shakespearean sonnet, as it is made up of three quatrains and a heroic couplet.
The rhyme scheme also supports this structure.
There is a cross rhyme in each quatrain (abab, cdcd, efef) and a pair rhyme in the couplet (gg).
The cross rhyme, makes the lines flow into eachothereach other and the pair rhyme at the end addadds emphasis to the message of the couplet.
The poem follows and I am big pentameter, which is an unstressed syllable followed by a stressed one.
This metre, when read out, imitates a heartbeat, which is supportive of the theme of love in the poem.
When looking at poetic devices one can notice a lot of repititionsrepetitions.

Words such as truth (v. 1, 8), lies/lie (v. 2, 13, 14) or false (v. 4, 7) are repeated throughout the poem to really emphasize this theme which makes the reader realize how important the topic of truthfulness is to the speaker.
The repititionsrepetitions of the word love (v. 1, 11, 12), also serves the purpospurpose of stressing this theme.

Another word that is repeated, is the word simple (v. 7, 8), whichShakespeare deliberately repeated, to make it clear to the reader, that the lies, which the narrator speaks of are not very big or meaningful, but only smalsmall lies and niceties.

When examining ShakespearShakespeare use of words, it is interesting that one can find a lot of wordwords having to do with time, age and youth (beauty), such as young (v. 5), old (v. 10) or years (v. 12).
This is aan often reoccuring them in ShakespearShakespeare poems ad it always influences how he talkes about love.
And in this sonnet, the age of the narrator is brought up as an insecurity, as he/she says my days are past the best (v. 6).
This makes the speaker more human and therefore more relateablerelatable for the reader.

body.p: A further stylistic device employed byShakespeare is the rhetorical question.But wherefore say she not she is unjust?And wherefore say not I that I am old?(v. 9, 10); these two rhetorical questions are the volta, the turning point of the poem and they invite the reader to think with the speaker and to follow his/her train of thought.Furthermore, there is a parallelism within these rhetorical questions, which expresses to the reader that the speaker and the beloved woman, are similar in a way, that being that they both lie to each other.

p.s: The personification love's best habit (v. 11) is used to make love seem like an entity, which has it'sits own will.
In the poem, love makes the speaker and the woman lie to each other, in order to make each other feel good.
age in love loves(v. 12) is a personification of age as well as an alliteration.
The alliteration helps to enrich the poetic effect and once again stressstresses the theme of love.
Whereas the personification expresses that the speaker is old and that his/her age has human qualities, such as a will.
It is then said, that the age, meaning the speaker does not want to be reminded of his/her age by his/her loved one.
Shakespeare employed this personification to stress the importance of age to the reader.
The metaphor she is made of truth (v. 1), creates an image of someone who is expremely truthful and whenShakespeare writes in the next line she lielies (v. 2), it makes her seem very dishonest.
Because of the antithesis thatShakespeare used, the reader thinks of the woman as a dishonest, not nice person, which also makes her human and understandable.
All in allShakespeare uses different formal and poetic devices, to on the other hand characterize the speaker and the woman.
In a very flawed and therefore human way and on the other hand he employs poetic devices to clearly state his message, that lies in a loving relationship are acceptable.
